{{Infobox civilian attack | title = July 2017 Pennsylvania murders | image = BucksCounty4.jpg | caption = Top Row: Meo and Finocchiaro;
Bottom Row: Patrick and Sturgis | location = [[Bucks County, Pennsylvania|Bucks County]], [[Pennsylvania]], [[United States]] | date = July 5, 2017 {{ndash}} July 7, 2017 | time = | timezone = | coordinates = | type = [[Shooting]], [[Murder]] | fatalities = 4 | victims = {{Plainlist| * Dean A. Finocchiaro, age 19 * Thomas C. Meo, age 21 * Jimi T. Patrick, age 19 * Mark R. Sturgis, age 22 }} | susperps = {{Plainlist| * Cosmo DiNardo, age 20 * Sean M. Kratz, age 20 }} }} Between July 5 and July 7, 2017, four young men were reported missing in [[Bucks County, Pennsylvania|Bucks County]], [[Pennsylvania]], [[United States]]. All were subsequently found murdered. The victims were Dean A. Finocchiaro, age 19; Thomas C. Meo, age 21; Jimi T. Patrick, age 19; and Mark R. Sturgis, age 22. The murders are suspected to have been carried out by cousins Cosmo DiNardo and Sean Michael Kratz, both age 20 at the times of the murder.{{cite web |last=Levenson|first=Eric |title=Cousins charged in homicides of four Pennsylvania men|url=http://www.cnn.com/2017/07/14/us/missing-pennsylvania-men-charges/index.html |website=[[CNN]] |date=14 July 2017 |accessdate=15 July 2017}} The four victims were murdered, in three separate incidents, after DiNardo arranged to sell them [[marijuana]].{{cite web |last=McCrone|first=Brian |title=Cosmo DiNardo, Sean Kratz Charged With Allegedly Killing Young Men at Bucks County Farm|url=http://www.nbcphiladelphia.com/news/local/Second-Man-Sean-Michael-Kratz-Held-in-Connection-to-Four-Murders-at-Bucks-County-Pennsylvania-Farm-Day-After-Cosmo-DiNardo-Confesses-434503403.html |website=[[NBC]] Philadelphia |accessdate=14 July 2017}} == Murder victims == The disappearances began on July 5, with Patrick being the first of the men to vanish. Two days later, on July 7, Meo, Finocchiaro, and Sturgis were also reported missing. Each of the four men was reported to be murdered the same day he went missing.{{cite web|url=https://bucks.crimewatchpa.com/da/29567/post/two-men-charged-homicide-four-solebury-slayings|title=Two Men Charged With Homicide in Four Solebury Slayings|date=14 July 2017|publisher=Bucks County District Attorney's Office}} * Jimi Taro Patrick (May 31, 1998 {{ndash}} July 5, 2017), a rising sophomore majoring in business at [[Loyola University Maryland]],{{cite web |title=The Latest: Maryland campus vigil held for 4 missing men |url=http://www.foxnews.com/us/2017/07/12/latest-man-held-after-trying-to-sell-missing-mans-car.html |website=[[FOX News]] |date=12 July 2017 |accessdate=14 July 2017}} was last seen around 6:00 PM on July 5 in [[Newtown Township, Bucks County, Pennsylvania|Newtown, Pennsylvania]]. He failed to show up for work the next day.{{cite web |last=Haag|first=Matthew |title=Search in Pennsylvania for 4 Missing Men Focuses on a Vast Farm |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/07/10/us/missing-men-bucks-county.html?action=click&contentCollection=U.S.&module=RelatedCoverage®ion=Marginalia&pgtype=article |website=New York Times |publisher=[[New York Times]] |date=10 July 2017 |accessdate=13 July 2017}} Patrick met DiNardo that night to buy four pounds of [[Cannabis (drug)|marijuana]]. * Dean A. Finocchiaro (December 18, 1997 {{ndash}} July 7, 2017) was last seen around 6:30 PM on July 7, being picked up by an unidentified person, possibly DiNardo or Kratz. His remains were found in a common grave on a [[Solebury Township, Bucks County, Pennsylvania|Solebury Township]] farm (owned by DiNardo's parents), along with the remains of Mark Sturgis and Thomas Meo on July 12, 2017. Finocchiaro's body was the first to be identified.{{cite web |last=Babay|first=Emily |title=Bucks County missing men: Who they are |url=http://www.philly.com/philly/news/pennsylvania/bucks-4-missing-men-mark-sturgis-jimi-patrick-dean-finocchiaro-thomas-meo-20170713.html |website=Philly |date=13 July 2017 |accessdate=13 July 2017}} Finocchiaro and DiNardo had a good relationship, with DiNardo saying that they were like cousins. As with Patrick, Finocchiaro had agreed to buy marijuana from DiNardo. This was the first murder in which Kratz was involved; the two men repeatedly shot Finocchiaro. His body was placed in a metal oil tank that had been converted to a pork roaster. * Mark R. Sturgis (November 20, 1994 {{ndash}} July 7, 2017) went to meet his friend Thomas C. Meo (January 30, 1996 {{ndash}} July 7, 2017) at around 6:00 PM on July 7. Both men worked for Sturgis' father's construction company. The two did not show up for work and calls to their cellphones went directly to voice mail. DiNardo met with Sturgis and Meo at a church to sell Meo marijuana. Meo and Sturgis were both shot as they exited their truck. When he ran out of ammunition, DiNardo drove over a still-alive Meo with a [[backhoe]], then placed both bodies in a metal tank that also held Finocchiaro's body. DiNardo attempted unsuccessfully to burn the bodies using gasoline. He used the backhoe to bury the tank containing the three bodies. DiNardo, a drug dealer, confessed to killing the four men; he said he did so because he felt cheated or threatened during drug transactions.{{cite web |url=https://articles.mlive.com/news/us-world/index.ssf/2017/07/suspect_in_pennsylvania_slayin.amp |title=Suspect in Pennsylvania slaying of 4 men burned bodies in a drum after drug deals, source said|first=Tanda |last=Gmiter|date=14 July 2017|work=MLive}} The only motive disclosed by investigators was that DiNardo said he wanted to set the victims up when they came to the farm to buy marijuana.{{cite web |url=http://www.delcotimes.com/article/DC/20170714/NEWS/170719777 |title=Grisly details revealed after 2 men charged in killing of missing men in Bucks|first1=Maryclaire| last1=Dale|first2=Anthony |last2=Izaguirre|date=14 July 2017|publisher=Associated Press}} == Investigation == On the afternoon of July 8, authorities tracked Finocchiaro's cell phone to a 90-acre farm{{Cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2017/jul/13/pennsylvania-missing-men-body-found|title=Man admits to killing four youths who went missing in Pennsylvania|last=Parker|first=Graham|date=2017-07-13|work=The Guardian|access-date=2017-07-16|language=en-GB|issn=0261-3077}} in the Solebury Township owned by DiNardo's parents, Antonio and Sandra DiNardo, who also own a cement and construction company.{{Cite web|url=http://www.cnn.com/2017/07/13/us/pennsylvania-missing-men/index.html|title=Lawyer: Man admits involvement in murders of 4 missing men|last=CNN|first=Nicole Chavez, Eric Levenson, Anne Woolsey and Emanuella Grinberg|website=CNN|access-date=2017-07-16}} While being investigated for the four July 2017 Pennsylvania murders, DiNardo also claimed to be responsible for at least two other killings in the previous five years in [[Philadelphia]].{{Cite web|url=http://philadelphia.cbslocal.com/2017/07/17/cosmo-dinardo-other-murders/|title=Sources: Cosmo DiNardo Confesses To 2 Other Killings|last=Holden|first=Joe|access-date=2017-07-21}} Investigators have yet to verify these claims.{{Cite news|url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/nation/2017/07/18/cosmo-dinardo-did-suspect-pennsylvania-murders-kill-any-others/488033001/|title=Pennsylvania murders: Did pot dealer kill any others?|work=USA TODAY|access-date=2017-07-21|language=en}} == Arrests == {{infobox criminal | name = Cosmo DiNardo | image = Cosmo Dinardo.png | caption = [[Mug shot]] {{ffdc|1=|log=2017 July 17|date=August 2017}} | image_size | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1997|1|21}} | birth_place = [[Bensalem, Pennsylvania]], U.S. | charge = Homicide, conspiracy to commit homicide, abuse of corpse, robbery, possession of instruments of crime | conviction_status = | occupation = }} {{infobox criminal | name = Sean Michael Kratz | image = Sean Kratz.png | image_size = 100 | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1997|2|14}} | birth_place = [[Bensalem, Pennsylvania]], U.S. | charge = Homicide, conspiracy to commit homicide, abuse of corpse, robbery, possession of instruments of crime | conviction_status = | occupation = }} Second cousins Cosmo DiNardo (born January 21, 1997) and Sean Michael Kratz (born February 14, 1997), both age 20, were charged in the murders. On July 10, DiNardo was arrested for an unrelated weapons charge. He was not allowed to own a firearm due to his [[schizophrenia]]; nevertheless, at least one of the firearms used by the perpetrators belonged to DiNardo's mother.{{cite web |last=McCausland|first=Phil |title=Cosmo Dinardo, Sean Michael Kratz Charged With Killing Four in Pennsylvania |url=http://www.nbcnews.com/news/us-news/cosmo-dinardo-second-man-charged-killing-four-pennsylvania-n783086 |website=[[NBC News]] |date=14 July 2017 |accessdate=14 July 2017}} Despite 30 run-ins with local police, DiNardo, the son of a wealthy businessman, had, for unexplained reasons, never been convicted of a crime.{{cite web |last=Hurdle| first=Jon |title=Man Admits to Killings of 4 Missing Men in Pennsylvania, Lawyer Says |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/07/13/us/bucks-county-missing-pennsylvania.html |website=[[New York Times]] |date=13 July 2017 |accessdate=14 July 2017}} DiNardo was later released after his father posted 10% of the $1 million bail. On July 12, DiNardo was arrested and charged for stealing and attempting to sell a car that belonged to Thomas Meo for $500.{{cite web |last=O'Malley|first=James |title=BREAKING: Cosmo DiNardo defense attorney says client confessed to 'participation in murders of four young men'|url=http://www.buckscountycouriertimes.com/news/crime/breaking-cosmo-dinardo-defense-attorney-says-client-confessed-to-participation/article_1d6dcb02-67d9-11e7-908b-1bc4ab8b99aa.html |website=Bucks County Courier Times |date=13 July 2017 |accessdate=13 July 2017}} Suspicion was also raised by the fact that Meo left his [[insulin]] in the car, something his family said was unusual for him to do. His bail was set at $5 million. The next day, DiNardo confessed to the murder of the four men. In exchange for his confession, prosecutors stated that they would not seek the [[death penalty]]. The day after his confession, DiNardo was charged with four counts of criminal homicide, conspiracy to commit criminal homicide, abuse of corpse, and 12 other charges. On July 14, Sean Michael Kratz was also charged with three counts of criminal homicide, conspiracy to commit criminal homicide, abuse of corpse, and two other charges. Unlike DiNardo, Kratz had a criminal history of [[burglary]], conspiracy, criminal trespassing, theft, receiving stolen property, and criminal mischief. On May 16, 2018, DiNardo pleaded guilty to four counts of murder and was sentenced to four consecutive life sentences.{{cite web|title=Sean Kratz Rejects Plea Deal, Cosmo DiNardo Pleads Guilty To Murder Charges In Deaths Of 4 Men|url=http://philadelphia.cbslocal.com/2018/05/16/cosmo-dinardo-sean-kratz-due-in-court-today-in-bucks-county-murders-jimi-patrick-tom-meo-mark-sturgis-dean-finocchiaro/|website=CBS Philly|date=16 May 2018 |accessdate=17 May 2018}}{{cite web|title=1 Bucks County Killer Pleads Guilty, Another Could Face Death Penalty for Murder Spree|url=https://www.nbcphiladelphia.com/news/local/Bucks-County-Killing-Spree-Case-Kratz-DiNardo-482778411.html|website=NBC Philadelphia|date=16 May 2018 |accessdate=17 May 2018}} On July 31, 2018, the newspaper outlet [[Philadelphia Media Network|philly.com]] reported Kratz denied his chance at a plea deal and that his trial is expected to begin in 2019.{{cite news |author1=Erin McCarthy |title=Families of Cosmo DiNardo’s victims stand with lawmakers pushing for tougher gun laws |url=https://www2.philly.com/philly/news/pennsylvania/cosmo-dinardo-murders-gun-legislation-bucks-county-20180731.html |accessdate=29 September 2018 |work=www.philly.com |publisher=[[Philadelphia Media Network]] |date=31 July 2018}} == See also == * [[Crime in Pennsylvania]] * [[List of people who disappeared]] == References == {{Reflist|30em}} == External links == * [https://bucks.crimewatchpa.com/sites/default/files/29567/post/attachments/dinardo_documents.pdf Criminal Complaint: Cosmo DiNardo] * [https://bucks.crimewatchpa.com/sites/default/files/29567/post/attachments/kratz_documents.pdf Criminal Complaint: Sean Michael Kratz] {{DEFAULTSORT:Pennsylvania murders}} [[Category:2010s missing person cases]] [[Category:2017 in Pennsylvania]] [[Category:2017 murders in the United States]] [[Category:Articles about multiple people]] [[Category:Bucks County, Pennsylvania]] [[Category:Crimes in Pennsylvania]] [[Category:Deaths by firearm in Pennsylvania]] [[Category:Formerly missing people found dead]] [[Category:July 2017 crimes in the United States]] [[Category:Loyola University Maryland]] [[Category:Mass murder in 2017]] [[Category:Missing person cases in Pennsylvania]] [[Category:Murder in Pennsylvania]]

'''Keaweaweʻulaokalani''' is a name shared by two short-lived princes and heirs to the throne of the [[Kingdom of Hawaii]]. Both were named after their father [[Kamehameha III]]. In [[Hawaiian language|Hawaiian]], the name means "the red trail of heaven", signifying the roadway by which the god descends from heaven.
==Earlier== {{Infobox royalty | name = Keaweaweʻulaokalani I | title = Prince of Hawaii | house = [[House of Kamehameha]] | father = [[Kamehameha III]] | mother = [[Kalama]] | birth_date = 1839 | birth_place = | death_date = 1839 | death_place = |}} '''Keaweaweʻulaokalani I''' (1839–1839) was the eldest son of [[Kamehameha III]] and his queen consort [[Kalama Hakaleleponi-i-Kapakuhaili]]. The baby boy was named after his father whose full name was Keaweawe{{okina}}ula Kiwala{{okina}}o Kauikeaouli Kaleiopapa Kalani Waiakua Kalanikau Iokikilo Kiwala{{okina}}o i ke kapu Kamehameha. The royal suffix o-Kalani was added in to signified this Prince of [[Heaven]].
The young Prince Keawe died shortly after his birth. His death left Kamehameha III again childless. His younger brother, Keaweaweʻulaokalani II, would not be born until 1842.
==Later== {{Infobox royalty | name = Keaweaweʻulaokalani II | title = Prince of Hawaii | house = [[House of Kamehameha]] | father = [[Kamehameha III]] | mother = [[Kalama]] | birth_date = January 14, 1842 | birth_place = | death_date = February 1842 | death_place = |}} '''Keaweaweʻulaokalani II''' (1842–1842) was the second son of [[Kamehameha III]] and his queen consort [[Kalama Hakaleleponi-i-Kapakuhaili]]. The baby boy was the namesake of his father and his brother.
Initially given in ''[[hānai]]'' to [[Kalākua Kaheiheimālie]], he was instead adopted or ''hānai'' by his grand aunt, [[Kekāuluohi]] and her husband [[Charles Kanaina|Kana{{okina}}ina]] when the old governess of Maui died not three days after his birth. The King promised that he would be sent to the [[Chiefs' Children's School]] once he was weaned and could walk. He soon developed a fever and died, at the age of only 31 days. Dr. Baldwin of Lahaina was convinced that the child was killed by traditional medicinal treatment.
==Family tree== {{Kamehameha family tree}}
==References== * {{cite web |url= http://www.royalark.net/Hawaii/hawaii7.htm |title=The Kamehameha Dynasty Genealogy (Page 7) |author=Christopher Buyers |accessdate=February 26, 2012 |work= Royal Ark web site }} * {{cite book|last=Kamakau|first=Samuel|authorlink=Samuel Kamakau|title=Ruling Chiefs of Hawaii|url=http://www.ulukau.org/elib/cgi-bin/library?c=chiefs&l=en|edition=Revised|year=1992|origyear=1961|publisher=[[Kamehameha Schools]] Press|location=Honolulu|isbn=0-87336-014-1|pages=264, 342, 388, 395}} * {{cite book |title= Speeches of His Majesty Kamehameha III: to the Hawaiian Legislature |author= [[Kamehameha III]] |page= 10 |publisher= Government Press |year=1861 |url= https://books.google.com/books?id=1U8gU7VqaY4C }} * {{cite book |chapter= Reality and Fantasy: The Foster Child in Hawaiian Myths and Customs |author= Katharine Luomala, University of Hawaii |title= Pacific Studies |year= 1987 |publisher= Brigham Young University Hawaii Campus |pages= 26 |url= https://ojs.lib.byu.edu/spc/index.php/PacificStudies/article/viewFile/9449/9098 |deadurl= yes |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20160304191704/https://ojs.lib.byu.edu/spc/index.php/PacificStudies/article/viewFile/9449/9098 |archivedate= 2016-03-04 |df= }} * {{cite book |title= The Hawaiian Chiefs' Children's School |author= [[Amos Starr Cooke]], Juliette Montague Cooke |editor=Mary Atherton Richards |url= https://books.google.com/books?id=kHBBAAAAIAAJ |publisher= C. E. Tuttle Company |page=126| origyear= 1937 |year= 1970}} * {{cite book |url= https://books.google.com/books?ei=t1NwT_6OJ5DKiAKB66i8BQ&id=HitzAAAAMAAJ |title= Moku'ula: Maui's sacred island |author= P. Christiaan Klieger |year= 1998 |publisher= [[Bishop Museum]] Press |location= Honolulu |isbn= 1-58178-002-8 |pages=53–54, 82}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Keaweaweulaokalani, Prince Of Hawaii}} [[Category:Articles about multiple people]] [[Category:Heirs apparent who never acceded]] [[Category:Princes of Hawaii]] [[Category:House of Kamehameha]] [[Category:1839 births]] [[Category:1839 deaths]] [[Category:1842 births]] [[Category:1842 deaths]] [[Category:Heirs to the Hawaiian throne]] [[Category:Burials at the Royal Mausoleum of Hawaii]] [[Category:Royalty of the Kingdom of Hawaii]]

revision.comment: /* Europe */Included new relevant poliglot in the proposed list of poliglots, Sir Richard F Burton, who spoke 29 languages.
revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=August 2015}}
A [[polyglotism|polyglot]] is a person with a command of many languages.<ref>{{cite web|title=polyglot | Collins Dictionary|url=https://www.collinsdictionary.com/dictionary/english/polyglot|website=Collins Dictionary|accessdate=4 December 2016}}</ref> A polyglot may also be called a [[multilingualism|multilingual person]]; the label "multilingual" is used for communities as well as individual speakers.
[[Richard Hudson (linguist)|Richard Hudson]], professor emeritus of [[linguistics]] at [[University College London]], coined the term "hyperpolyglot" for "people who know dozens of languages well".<ref>{{cite book|last=Hudson |first=Richard |year=2008 |chapter=Word grammar, cognitive linguistics, and second language learning and teaching |title=Handbook of Cognitive Linguistics and Second Language Acquisition |editor=P. Robinson and N. Ellis |pages=89–113 |publisher=Routledge}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=The Polyglot of Bologna |url=http://publicdomainreview.org/2012/06/26/the-polyglot-of-bologna/ |last=Erard |first=Michael |date=June 2012 |publisher=Public Domain Review |accessdate=16 May 2014}}</ref> Other scholars apply the label to speakers of even more languages: twelve, sixteen, or in the most extreme cases, even fifty or more.<ref name="Poly">{{cite web|last=Erard |first=Michael |title=How many languages is it possible for a person to speak? |url=http://spinner.cofc.edu/linguist/archives/2005/11/how_many_langua_1.html |publisher=The Five Minute Linguist |accessdate=11 December 2012 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100413031021/http://spinner.cofc.edu/linguist/archives/2005/11/how_many_langua_1.html |archivedate=13 April 2010 |date=3 November 2005 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref>
It is difficult to judge which individuals are polyglots, as there is no uncontroversial definition for what it means to "master" a language, and because it is not always clear where to distinguish a [[dialect]] from a [[language]]. Being able to communicate in a language does not mean the person has "mastered" a language. There are far fewer who have attained higher levels of multi-linguistic skill, and there is no basis for testing those levels, or at least those levels of ability have not been noted here.
This list consists of people who have been noted in news media, historical texts, or academic work as speaking five or more languages fluently. For general discussion of the phenomenon, including discussion of polyglot [[savant syndrome|savants]], see [[polyglotism]].
== Notable living polyglots == <!-- do not enter names unless they have a corresponding article in the English Wikipedia to assert notability -->
The 2012 book ''Babel No More''<ref>{{cite web|title=Babel No More|url=http://www.babelnomore.com/|work=babelnomore.com|publisher=Jamie-Lee Nardone at Duckworth Publishers|accessdate=14 April 2012|year=2013}}</ref> by [[Michael Erard]] highlights some polyglots around the globe, including Alexander Argüelles. Canada's Global TV also brought out a piece on hyperpolyglots on their 16x9 show, entitled "Word Play",<ref name="16x9onglobal">{{cite web|title=Word Play|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=bppUq5IKZrM|work=YouTube|publisher=Google, Inc|accessdate=7 May 2012|author=16x9onglobal|format=Video upload|date=7 May 2012}}</ref> featuring Canadian polyglots Axel Van Hout, Alexandre Coutu, Steven Kaufmann, James Chang and Keith Swayne. Tim Doner (US) and Richard Simcott (UK) also appear in the programme to describe their experiences speaking multiple languages.
===Africa=== * [[Peter Kodwo Appiah Turkson]], cardinal of the Catholic Church (Ghana): English, [[Fante language|Fante]], French, Italian, German, and Hebrew<ref>{{cite news|title=Who will be the next pope? The contenders for Vatican's top job|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2013/feb/11/next-pope-contenders-vatican-job|accessdate=14 April 2013|newspaper=The Guardian|date=11 February 2013|author=Sam Jones|author2=Afua Hirsch|location=London}}</ref> * [[Dikembe Mutombo]], athlete (Zaire): English, French, Portuguese, Spanish, Tshiluba, Swahili, Lingala, and two other central African languages.{{which|date=August 2017}}<ref>{{cite web|title=Dikembe Mutombo|url=http://www.nba.com/playerfile/dikembe_mutombo/bio.html|work=NBA.com|publisher=NBA Media Ventures, LLC|accessdate=14 April 2013|year=2013}}</ref> * [[Trevor Noah]], entertainer (South Africa): [[English language|English]], [[Xhosa language|Xhosa]], [[Zulu language|Zulu]], [[Sotho language|Sesotho]], [[Tswana language |Setswana]], [[Tsonga language|Tsonga]], [[Afrikaans language|Afrikaans]], and [[German language|German]].<ref name="nytimes33114">{{cite news|authorlink=Dave Itzkoff|last1=Itzkoff|first1=Dave|title=Trevor Noah to Succeed Jon Stewart on ‘The Daily Show’|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2015/03/31/arts/television/trevor-noah-to-succeed-jon-stewart-on-the-daily-show.html?_r=1|accessdate=11 April 2015|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=31 March 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.birminghampost.co.uk/whats-on/comedy-gigs/south-african-comedian-trevor-noah-6319931|title=South African comedian Trevor Noah to play Birmingham’s Glee Club|author=Roz Laws|date=22 November 2013|work=birminghampost}}</ref> *[[Cyril Ramaphosa]], politician (South Africa): [[South African English language|English]], [[Afrikaans language|Afrikaans]], [[Venda language|Venda]], [[Tsonga language|Tsonga]], [[Zulu language|Zulu]], [[Xhosa language|Xhosa]], [[Sesotho language|Sesotho]], [[Setswana language|Setswana]], [[Northern Sotho language|Northern Sotho]] and [[Southern Ndebele language |Southern Ndebele]] .
=== Americas === * [[Alexander Argüelles]], United States: A dozen languages<ref>Erard, Michael (2012). ''Babel No More: The Search for the World's Most Extraordinary Language Learners''. New York: Free Press.</ref> *[[Andrew Divoff]], Venezuela, actor and producer: English, Spanish, Italian, French, Catalan, Russian, German, and Portuguese<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://threemarmbrewing.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/01/ExcerptLakeArrowheadMagazine.pdf|title=A 'Bad Guy' With a Heart of Gold|last=Lanyon|first=Mary-Justine|date=Winter 2015–2016|work=Lake Arrowhead Magazine, pp, 41-43.|access-date=30 January 2018|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=}}</ref> *[[Pope Francis]], Argentina: Spanish, Italian<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2013/mar/13/new-pope-thirteen-key-facts|title=Pope Francis: 13 key facts about the new pontiff|date=13 March 2013|work=The Guardian|location=London|accessdate=13 March 2013}}</ref> French,<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.news.va/it/news/briefing-di-padre-lombardi|title=Briefing di padre Lombardi|date=14 March 2013|publisher=The Vatican Today|accessdate=14 March 2013}}</ref> Portuguese<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.corriere.it/cronache/13_marzo_14/papa-francesco-primo-giorno_9d687672-8c78-11e2-ab2c-711cc67f5f67.shtml|title=Francis and those humble gestures by the Pope, he does not sit on a throne, paying the bill at the hotel|date=14 March 2013|publisher=Corriere Della Sera|language=it|accessdate=1 April 2013}}</ref> English<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2013/mar/14/pope-francis-first-day|title=Pope Francis, first day after election|date=14 March 2013|publisher=The Guardian|location=London|author1=Peter Walker, Paul Owen|author2=David Batty|lastauthoramp=yes|accessdate=19 March 2013}}</ref><ref name="languages">Willey, David, [https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-europe-21986185 News analysis sidebar to "Pope Francis delivers Easter plea for peace"], BBC News, 31 March 2013, Retrieved 31 March 2013</ref> and Latin<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.catholicnews.com/data/stories/cns/1301486.htm|title=Can't chant, can't speak English? Pope says it's because he's tone-deaf|last=Glatz|first=Carol|date=2 April 2013|publisher=Catholic News Service|accessdate=15 September 2013|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=http://webarchive.loc.gov/all/20130402184851/http%3A//www.catholicnews.com/data/stories/cns/1301486.htm|archivedate=2 April 2013|df=dmy-all}}</ref> * [[Viggo Mortensen]], Danish actor. He speaks fluent English, Danish, and Spanish, is conversational in French and Italian, and understands Norwegian and Swedish.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,1867124,00.html|work=Time|title=10 Questions for Viggo Mortensen|date=December 17, 2008}}</ref> He also has some knowledge of [[Catalan language|Catalan]].<ref>{{YouTube|elivRosJSNQ|Viggo Mortensen speaks Catalan}}, Sitges Film Festival 2009.</ref> * [[Édgar Ramírez]], Venezuela, actor and former journalist. Spanish, English, Italian, French, German, and Portuguese<ref>{{cite news |last=Mendoza |first=Eduardo |title=Venezolanos entre los Políglotas más Famosos del Mundo. + Édgar Ramírez |date=January 4, 2017 |work=Eduardo Mendoza|url=https://profesoreduardomendoza.wordpress.com/2017/01/04/venezolanos-entre-los-poliglotas-mas-famosos-del-mundo-edgar-ramirez/|access-date=9 June 2018 }}</ref> *[[Henry Lau]], entertainer, Canada: English, [[Standard Chinese|Mandarin]], [[Korean language|Korean]], French and [[Chinese Language|Cantonese]]<ref name="language">{{cite news|url=http://enewsworld.interest.me/enews/contents.asp?idx=37385|title =Super Junior-M′s Henry Revealed to be Mystery SM Solo Singer| accessdate=May 31, 2013|author=Jeon, Su Mi|newspaper=CJ E&M enewsWorld|date=May 30, 2013}}</ref> *[[Michael Tibollo]], politician, Canada: English, French, German, Spanish and Italian<ref>[http://www.tibollo.net/team/MichaelATibollo.html]</ref> * [[Janet Hsieh]], actress, United States: English, Spanish, French, Mandarin, and [[Taiwanese Hokkien|Taiwanese]].<ref>Koh, Bernard.[http://justwoman.asiaone.com/Just%2BWoman/News/Celebrities/Story/A1Story20080603-68705.html "But I speak only five languages"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110707174230/http://justwoman.asiaone.com/Just%2BWoman/News/Celebrities/Story/A1Story20080603-68705.html |date=7 July 2011 }},''The Straits Times'', Mon, Jun 02, 2008. Retrieved on 12/02/2011.</ref> *[[Boris Kodjoe]], actor, United States: Fluently speaks [[German language|German]], [[English language|English]], [[French language|French]] and some [[Spanish language|Spanish]].
===Asia===
* <!-- Seyeong Oh is a former banker. He is fluent in Korean, Japanese, Chinese, English, Spanish, Russian, and German. --> *[[Seungri]] is a Korean [[singer]] and a member of [[Big Bang (South Korean band)|Big Bang]].He can speak Korean, English, Japanese, Chinese and is currently learning Cantonese. * [[José Rizal]] was a Filipino revolutionary who was fluent in 12 languages, namely Filipino, Italian, Portuguese, Dutch, Latin, Greek, English, Spanish, Japanese, German, French, and Spanish-Castillan. * [[Jackson Wang]] is a Chinese [[singer]], [[rapper]] and [[dancer]] from Hong Kong and a member of [[Got7]]. He speaks Cantonese, Korean, Mandarin, English, Shanghainese, Japanese and basic French.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=tlyjcA2Tpkg|website=Youtube|title=《透鲜滴星期天》精彩花絮: 王嘉尔秀法语问懵尚雯婕 Fresh Sunday Recap【湖南卫视官方版】|accessdate=6 January 2017}}</ref> *[[P. V. Narasimha Rao|PV Narasimha Rao]] was a popular Indian Politician who served as the [[List of Prime Ministers of India|9th]] [[Prime Minister of India]] (1991–1996). He was very fluent in many languages including his mother tongue Telugu, Marathi, Hindi, English, Tamil, Urdu, Kannada, Oriya, Sanskrit, French, and Spanish. He was able to speak 17 languages.<ref>{{Citation|title=P. V. Narasimha Rao|date=2018-07-31|url=https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=P._V._Narasimha_Rao&oldid=852784472|work=Wikipedia|language=en|access-date=2018-08-06}}</ref> * [[Asin]] is an Indian actress who can speak Malayalam (her mother-tongue), Tamil, Telugu, Hindi, English and French. She speaks some Marathi, Italian, Spanish and German.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dnaindia.com/entertainment/report-asin-thottumkal-knows-seven-languages-1970789|title=Asin Thottumkal knows seven languages! - Latest News & Updates at Daily News & Analysis|date=21 March 2014|publisher=}}</ref> * [[Jackie Chan]] is a Hong Kong martial artist, actor, film director, producer, stuntman, and singer. He is fluent in 11 languages including: Spanish، English، Japanese، German، Korean، Cantonese and Standard Cantonese.<ref>[https://www.google.com/search?client=firefox-b&ei=NdpmW_WmHuXt6ATSnbGABg&q=jackie+chan+languages&oq=jackie+chan+lang&gs_l=psy-ab.1.0.0j0i22i30k1l9.2504.3739.0.4617.5.5.0.0.0.0.239.709.2-3.3.0....0...1c.1.64.psy-ab..2.3.708...0i67k1.0.743mtYvakvU jackie languages]</ref> * Ambassador [[Naela Chohan]] is a polyglot, [[artist]], and current Ambassador of Pakistan to Australia and former Ambassador of Pakistan for Latin America. Tongo|Surinamese]]. * [[Richard Simcott]] lives in Chester UK, is a hyperpolyglot who speaks 16 languages fluently, but can speak about 30 languages in total to some degree.<ref>Robson, David 2015 "How to learn 30 languages" BBC http://www.bbc.com/future/story/20150528-how-to-learn-30-languages </ref>. He is regarded as one of the most proficient Polyglots in the UK.<ref>"an-extraordinary-story-richard-simcott" thepolyglotdream Jan 13, 2013 http://www.thepolyglotdream.com/an-extraordinary-story-richard-simcott/</ref><ref> Fotheringham, John Jan 16, 2015 http://l2mastery.com "Interview with Hyperpolyglot Richard Simcott of SpeakingFluently.com"</ref> Simcott can learn languages in very short periods of time, and has passed C1 [[Common European Framework of Reference for Languages|Fluency]] exams after 3 months of study. * Yaroslav Shmarov<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://london.cn.ua/articles/view/114|title=Полиглоты Чернигова 25.09.2011 - Центр иностранных языков Лондон|website=london.cn.ua|access-date=2018-01-30}}</ref>, lives in [[Chernihiv]] ([[Ukraine]]), is fluent in 8 languages and has limited knowledge of many other [[Languages of Europe|European languages]]. He is native in [[Ukrainian language|Ukrainian]] and [[Russian language|Russian]], and speaks fluent [[English language|English]], [[German language|German]], [[French language|French]]<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://london.cn.ua/articles/view/131|title=31.05.2012 Ярослав: Как я сдавал Международный Экзамен DELF/DALF - Центр иностранных языков Лондон|website=london.cn.ua|access-date=2018-02-03}}</ref>, [[Spanish language|Spanish]], [[Italian language|Italian]] and [[Polish language|Polish]], in which he actively practices as a foreign language professor. He also has limited knowledge of [[Czech language|Czech]], [[Belarusian language|Belarusian]], and [[Portuguese language|Portuguese]] and other [[Slavic languages|Slavic]] and [[romance languages]]. * [[Nico Rosberg]], [[Formula One]] World Champion, fluent in German, English, French, Italian and Spanish.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2014/jul/04/world-cup-nico-rosberg-mercedes-british-grand-prix}}</ref> * [[Željko Joksimović]], Serbian recording artist and multi-instrumentalist is multi-lingual, being fluent in [[Greek language|Greek]], [[English language|English]], [[Russian language|Russian]], [[Polish language|Polish]] and [[French language|French]] as well as his native [[Serbian language|Serbian]].<ref>[http://dnevnik.hr/showbizz/glazba/najzgodniji-pjevac-na-balkanu-zeljko-joksimovic-zapalio-arenu.html Željko Joksimović: Ne promatram se kao da sam zgodan!]. ===Oceania===
* [[Eliana Rubashkyn]], New Zealand pharmacist, gender refugee, chemist and polyglot, speaks with fluency 6 languages [[Spanish language|Spanish]], [[Russian language|Russian]], [[Chinese Mandarin]], [[English language|English]], [[Portuguese language|Portuguese]] and [[Hebrew]].<ref>{{cite web|url = http://www.newshub.co.nz/home/new-zealand/2015/08/gender-refugee-hopes-for-nz-citizenship.html |title =Gender refugee hopes for NZ Citizenship|date = 26 July 2015|work = Newshub}}</ref>
== Notable deceased reputed polyglots == The following list consists of deceased individuals who are associated with claims of polyglotism, by date of birth.
===Antiquity and Middle Ages=== * [[Mithridates VI of Pontus]] (134–63 BC) could supposedly speak the languages of all twenty-two nations within his kingdom.<ref>"Mithridates, who was king of twenty-two nations, administered their laws in as many languages, and could harangue each of them, without employing an interpreter:" Pliny the Elder, ''Natural History'', VII, 24.</ref> * [[Cleopatra VII]] (69–30 BC), the last ruling Pharaoh of Ancient Egypt, could, according to the Roman biographer [[Plutarch]], speak nine languages and was the only member of her dynasty who could speak Egyptian as well as her native Greek.<ref>"she could pass from one language to another; so that there were few of the barbarian nations that she answered by an interpreter; to most of them she spoke herself, as to the Ethiopians, Troglodytes, Hebrews, Arabians, Syrians, Medes, Parthians, and many others, whose language she had learnt; which was all the more surprising because most of the kings, her predecessors, scarcely gave themselves the trouble to acquire the Egyptian tongue, and several of them quite abandoned the Macedonian." Plutarch, ''Antony'', 27.3–4</ref> * [[al-Farabi]] (872–950/951), a [[Tajik people|Persian]] [[polymath]] who mastered many languages.<ref>[[Rom Landau]], ''Islam and the Arabs'', [[Routledge]] (2013), p. 147</ref>
===Modern age, pre-17th century=== * [[Thotagamuwe Sri Rahula Thera]] (1408–1491)<ref name="jo">{{cite journal | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=c6VhAAAAMAAJ&q=Sri+Rahula+1408+-+1491&dq=Sri+Rahula+1408+-+1491&hl=en&sa=X&ei=RlFYVM6HJ4ySuQSOwoL4AQ&ved=0CCAQ6AEwAQ | title=Journal of the Royal Asiatic Society of Sri Lanka | author=Royal Asiatic Society, Sri Lanka | journal= | year=2004 | volume= 47–48}}</ref> was a [[Buddhist monk]] and an eminent scholar<ref name="hbk">{{cite book | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=irqsAgAAQBAJ&printsec=frontcover#v=onepage&q&f=false | title=Handbook of Asian Education: A Cultural Perspective | publisher=[[Routledge]] | author=Zhao, Yong | year=2011 | page=399}}</ref> who lived in the fifteenth century in [[Sri Lanka]].<ref name="BDS">{{cite web | url=http://www.lakehouse.lk/budusarana/2006/01/29/Budu13.pdf | title=Ven. Thotagamuwe Sri Rahula Thera Scholar monk par excellence | publisher=Lake House | date=29 January 2006 | accessdate=1 October 2013 | author=Himbutana, Gopitha Peiris | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131004220213/http://www.lakehouse.lk/budusarana/2006/01/29/Budu13.pdf | archivedate=4 October 2013 | df=dmy-all }}</ref> He was a polyglot who was given the title "''Shad Bhasha Parameshwara''" due to his mastery in six oriental languages which prevailed in the [[Indian subcontinent]].<ref name="apab">{{cite web | url=http://sundaytimes.lk/000220/plus3.html#3LABEL3 | title=A taste of Sinhala : What apabbransa are you jabbering? | date=20 February 2000 | publisher=The Sunday Times | accessdate=26 September 2014 | author=Disanayaka, Professor. J. B.}}</ref> *[[Elizabeth I of England]] (1533–1603) could speak ten languages: English, French, Spanish, Italian, Dutch, Latin, Welsh, Cornish, Scottish and Irish. The Venetian Ambassador once said: "it is as if she possessed these languages as if they were her mother tongue".
===17th century=== * [[Athanasius Kircher]] (1601?–1680), a German Jesuit polymath and scholar, claimed knowledge of twelve languages; among them: [[Latin]], [[Greek language|Greek]], [[Hebrew language|Hebrew]], [[Aramaic language|Aramaic]], [[Syriac language|Syriac]], [[Coptic language|Coptic]], as well as several modern languages. He also pioneered the study of [[Egyptian hieroglyphs]] and [[Classical Chinese]] characters.{{Citation needed|date=April 2014}} * [[Johannes Matthiae Gothus]] (1592-1670) * [[John Milton]] (1608–1674), an English poet who is famous for the epic work ''[[Paradise Lost]]'', could speak English, Latin, French, German, Greek, Hebrew, Italian, Spanish, Aramaic, Syriac, and [[Old English]]. Milton coined 630 terms in the English language.<ref>{{cite news|title=John Milton – our greatest word-maker|url=https://www.theguardian.com/uk/2008/jan/28/britishidentity.johncrace|accessdate=15 April 2013|newspaper=The Guardian|date=28 January 2008|author=John Crace|location=London}}</ref> * [[Wojciech Bobowski]] or Ali Ufki (1610–1675), a [[Polish people|Polish]] musician based in the [[Ottoman Empire]] who mastered sixteen languages. * [[Gavril Stefanović Venclović]] (1670–1749) was a Serbian priest, writer, poet, orator, philosopher, polyglot, and [[Illuminated manuscript|illuminator]].
===18th century=== * [[Adam František Kollár]] (1718–1783), a Slovak writer, spoke Slovak, Czech, Serbian, Polish, Rusin, Russian, Belarusian, Ukrainian, Slovenian, Croatian, Bulgarian, Hungarian, German, Latin, Greek, Hebrew, Turkish, Chinese, Persian, Arabic, Italian, Romanian, French, Dutch, and English.<ref>Kopčan Vojtech:Adam František Kollár ako orientalista. In: Literárnomuzejný letopis č. 16, Martin, Matica slovenská, 1985, s. 171–178</ref> * [[Maria Gaetana Agnesi]] (1718–1799) was an Italian mathematician, philosopher, theologian and humanitarian. Agnesi was known as "the seven-language orator" already in her childhood, since she was fluent with Italian, French, Greek, Hebrew, Spanish, German and Latin. * [[Zaharije Orfelin]] (1726–1785) was a Serbian writer, artist, and polyglot who spoke more than 10 languages, and understood many more. * [[Jovan Rajić]] (1726–1801) was a Serbian writer and cleric who spoke and wrote in many languages in his time. He was born in the [[Habsburg Empire]] where one had to know German, Hungarian, Latin, Italian, Romanian, and all the Slavic languages if one wanted to achieve a standing. * [[Dositej Obradović]] (1739–1811) was a Serbian writer. Obradović spoke and wrote in German, French, Italian, English, Greek, Albanian, Latin, Turkish, Hungarian, Romanian and all of the Slavic languages, including Russian and Church Slavonic. * [[Sir William Jones]] (1746–1794), an Anglo-Welsh [[philologist]] known for founding [[comparative linguistics]] through proposing the existence of a relationship between European and Indian languages (the [[Indo-European Languages]]). Alongside his native [[English language|English]] and [[Welsh language|Welsh]] languages, he learned [[Greek language|Greek]], [[Latin]], [[Persian language|Persian]], [[Arabic language|Arabic]], [[Hebrew language|Hebrew]] and the basics of Chinese writing at an early age. In all, Jones could speak forty-one languages (at least thirteen fluently).<ref>[[Edward Said]], ''[[Orientalism (book)|Orientalism]]'' New York: Random House, page 77.</ref><ref name=jones1824discourses>{{Cite book | publisher = Printed for C. S. Arnold | last = Jones | first = Sir William | page = 28 | title = Discourses delivered before the Asiatic Society: and miscellaneous papers, on the religion, poetry, literature, etc., of the nations of India | year = 1824 }}</ref> * [[Noah Webster]] (1758–1843), a [[lexicographer]], [[English-language spelling reform|English spelling reformer]], and author, mastered twenty-three languages.{{Citation needed|date=May 2013}} * [[Giuseppe Caspar Mezzofanti]] (1774–1849), an Italian Cardinal, knew the following thirty-nine languages, speaking many fluently and teaching some:<ref>C. W. Russel, D.D., 1863, Longman & Green, London</ref> Biblical Hebrew, Rabbinical Hebrew, Arabic, Coptic, Ancient Armenian, Modern Armenian, Persian, Turkish, Albanian, Maltese, Ancient Greek, Modern Greek, Latin, Italian, Spanish, Portuguese, French, German, Swedish, Danish, Dutch, English, Illyrian, Russian, Polish, Czech, Hungarian, Chinese, Syriac, Ge'ez, Hindustani, Amharic, Gujarati, Basque, Romanian, and Algonquin. * [[Sándor Kőrösi Csoma]] (1784-1842), a Hungarian philologist and Orientalist, author of the first Tibetan-English dictionary and grammar book, was literate in at least eighteen languages, including Latin, ancient Greek, Hebrew, Arabic, French, German, English, Russian, Slavic, Turkish, Persian, Hindustani, Sanskrit, Tibetan, Bengali, Pashto, Marathi, and probably also Romanian, apart from his native Hungarian. * [[Jean-François Champollion]] (1790–1832), a French classical scholar, philologist, and [[Oriental studies|orientalist]], was the first to decipher the inscription on the [[Rosetta Stone]], an achievement that facilitated the translation of the [[Egyptian hieroglyphs|Egyptian Hieroglyphs]]—the titles "Father of Egyptology"<ref name="Tour">{{cite web|title=Jean Francois Champollion: The Father of Egyptology|url=http://www.touregypt.net/featurestories/champollion.htm|work=Tour Egypt|publisher=Tour Egypt|accessdate=30 April 2013|author=Jimmy Dunn writing as John Warren|year=1996–2013}}</ref> and "the founder of scientific Egyptology" have since been bestowed upon Champollion.<ref name="Fame">{{cite web|title=Jean Francois Champollion and the Rosetta Stone|url=http://www.tihof.org/honors/champollion.htm|work=Translator Interpreter Hall of Fame|publisher=Translator Interpreter Hall of Fame|accessdate=30 April 2013|year=2000–2003|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130227053450/http://www.tihof.org/honors/champollion.htm|archivedate=27 February 2013|df=dmy-all}}</ref> He specialized in Oriental languages while he was a student at the College de France between 1807 and 1809, and his linguistic repertoire eventually consisted of [[Latin]], [[Greek language|Greek]], Sanskrit, [[Pahlavi scripts|Pahlavi]], Arabic, Persian, Coptic, Ethiopic, Zend, and his native French.<ref name="Tour" /><ref name="Fame" /><ref>{{cite web|title=Gallery of Philologists Jean-François Champollion 23 December 1790 – 4 March 1832|url=http://www.umass.edu/wsp/philology/gallery/champollion.html|work=University of Massachusetts Amherst|publisher=University of Massachusetts Amherst|accessdate=30 April 2013|author=E Bruce Brooks|year=2001}}</ref> * [[John Bowring]] (1792–1872), an English political economist, traveler, writer, and the fourth governor of Hong Kong. Reputed to have known over two hundred languages, and to have had varying speaking ability in one hundred. * [[Matija Čop]] (1797–1835) was a Slovenian polymath and linguist, and was said to speak nineteen languages, among which were his native Slovene, Latin, ancient Greek, German, English, French, Italian, Serbian, Polish, Ukrainian, Czech, Spanish, Russian, Portuguese, Hungarian, Occitan and Hebrew.
===19th century=== * [[Jan Prosper Witkiewicz]] (known as: Yan Vitkevich) (1808–1839) a Polish orientalist, explorer and diplomat in the Russian service, agent of Russia at Kabul just before the [[First Anglo-Afghan War]] a part of [[the Great Game]]. He knew 19 languages i.e.: Polish, Russian, French, German and English. In exile he learned Persian, Pashto and several Turkic languages, memorized the [[Qur'an]] in Arabic.<ref>Janusz Fedirko: Szalony plan wyzwolenia Polski, cz. I, "Alma Mater", 2008 r., nr. 102–104 [http://www2.almamater.uj.edu.pl/102/07.pdf].</ref> * [[C. V. Runganada Sastri]] (1819-1881) was an Indian jurist described as 'a linguist unrivalled in India'. He was known to have mastered [[English language|English]], [[Tamil language|Tamil]], [[Telugu language|Telugu]], [[Malayalam]], [[Kannada]], [[Marathi language|Marathi]], [[Hindustani language|Urdu and Hindi]], [[Farsi]], [[Arabic]], [[Sanskrit]], [[Latin]], [[Greek language|Greek]], [[French language|French]], and [[German language|German]]; he was additionally known to have had some proficiency in [[Hebrew language|Hebrew]]. * [[Friedrich Engels]] (1820–1895), a German-English industrialist, [[social science|social scientist]], and cofounder of [[Marxism|Marxist theory]] alongside [[Karl Marx]], mastered over twenty languages.<ref>{{cite web|title=Frederick Engels|url=http://www.marxists.org/archive/lafargue/1905/08/engels.htm|work=Marxists Internet Archive (from The Social Democrat journal)|publisher=Marxists Internet Archive|accessdate=15 April 2013|author=Paul Lafargue|author2=Jacques Bonhomme |date=15 August 1905}}</ref> *[[Sir Richard Francis Burton]] (1821–1890) was a British explorer, [[geographer]], translator, writer, soldier, [[oriental studies|orientalist]], [[Cartography|cartographer]], [[ethnologist]], spy, [[linguistics|linguist]], poet, [[fencing|fencer]], and diplomat; his extraordinary knowledge of languages and cultures amounted to having "mastered at least twenty-five languages—or forty, if distinct dialects are counted."<ref>McLynn, Frank (1990), ''Of No Country: An Anthology of the Works of Sir Richard Burton'', [[Charles Scribner's Sons|Scribner's]], pp. 5–6.</ref> * [[Heinrich Schliemann]] (1822–1890) was a German businessman and a pioneer of field archaeology. He was an advocate of the historical reality of places mentioned in the works of Homer. Schliemann was an archaeological excavator of Hissarlik, now presumed to be the site of Troy, along with the Mycenaean sites Mycenae and Tiryns. Mastered over fifteen languages. * [[Pedro II of Brazil|Pedro II, Emperor of Brazil]] (1825–1891) had a deep interest in many different arts and sciences. His passion for [[linguistics]] prompted lifelong studies of new languages, and he was able to speak and write not only his native [[Portuguese language|Portuguese]] but also [[Latin]], [[French language|French]], [[German language|German]], [[English language|English]], [[Italian language|Italian]], [[Spanish language|Spanish]], [[Greek language|Greek]], [[Arabic language|Arabic]], [[Hebrew language|Hebrew]], [[Sanskrit]], [[Chinese language|Chinese]], [[Occitan language|Occitan]] and [[Tupi language|Tupi]].<ref>See: * {{harvnb|Carvalho|2007|p=226}}, * {{harvnb|Olivieri|1999|p=7}}, * {{harvnb|Schwarcz|1998|p=428}}, * {{harvnb|Besouchet|1993|p=401}}, * {{harvnb|Lira 1977, Vol 2|p=103}}.</ref> * [[Pashko Vasa]] - (1825–1892) also known as Vaso Pasha, Wasa Pasha or Vaso Pashë Shkodrani, was an Albanian writer, poet and publicist. He had perfect knowledge of a number of foreign languages: Italian, French, Turkish and Greek. He also knew some English and Serbian, and in later years learned Arabic.<ref>Robert Elsie (24 December 2012). A Biographical Dictionary of Albanian History. I.B.Tauris. pp. 459–461. {{ISBN|978-1-78076-431-3}}.</ref> * [[Konstandin Kristoforidhi]] (1826–1895) was an Albanian translator and scholar. He is mostly known for having translated into Albanian the New Testament for the first time in the Gheg Albanian dialect in 1872. He knew Albanian (Tosk and Gheg dialects), Greek, Latin, Hebrew, English, Italian, Turkish, Bulgarian, Arabic, French, German. * [[Georg Sauerwein]] (1831–1904) was a German publisher, polyglot, poet, and linguist. Sauerwein mastered about seventy-five languages, including: Latin, ancient Greek, modern Greek, Hebrew, French, Italian, Spanish, Basque, Portuguese, English, Welsh, Cornish, Irish, Scottish Gaelic, Manx Gaelic, Dutch, Danish, Icelandic, Norwegian, Swedish, Sami, Finnish, Estonian, Latvian, Lithuanian, Polish, Russian, Belarusian, Ukrainian, Czech, Slovak, Bulgarian, Sorbian, Serbian, Croatian, Hungarian, Romanian, Albanian, Turkish, Azerbaijani, Chuvash (a Turkic language), Tamil, Kashgar (spoken in Siberia, similar to the language of Uzbekistan), Kumyk (spoken in Siberia), Persian, Armenian, Georgian, Sanskrit, Romani, Hindustani, Ethiopian, Tigrinya (another language of Ethiopia), Coptic or ancient Egyptian, Arabic, Malagasy (the language of Madagascar), Malay, Samoan, Hawaiian, different dialects of Chinese, and Aneitum (a language spoken in the New Hebrides). * [[Pétrus Ky]] (1837–1898), a Vietnamese scholar, was proficient in French, English, Latin, Greek, Hindi, Japanese, as well as in Chinese, Spanish, Malay, Lao, Thai and Burmese. * [[James Augustus Henry Murray]] (1837–1915), was a Scottish lexicographer, instrumental in the creation of the Oxford English Dictionary, and its primary editor from 1879 until his death. In an application letter written to the British Museum Library in November 1866, he claimed abilities in Italian, French, Catalan, Spanish, and Latin, and "in a less degree" Portuguese, Provençal, Dutch, German, Flemish, and Danish. The letter also referred to Murray's study of Celtic, Russian, Persian, Hebrew, and Syriac, among other languages and dialects.<ref>{{cite book|last=Winchester|first=Simon|title=The Meaning of Everything: The Story of the Oxford English Dictionary|year=2003|publisher=Oxford University Press|location=New York}}</ref> * [[Yaqub Sanu]] (1839–1912), Egyptian journalist. * [[Hagop Baronian]] (1843–1891), notable [[Armenian people|Armenian]] writer and playwright. He was fluent in 6 languages including [[French language|French]], [[Italian language|Italian]], [[Greek language|Greek]], [[Turkish language|Turkish]], [[Bulgarian language|Bulgarian]] and his native [[Armenian language|Armenian]] * [[Chiragh Ali]] (1844–1895), an Islamic scholar who, apart from his native [[Urdu language|Urdu]], mastered [[Persian language|Persian]], [[Arabic]], [[English language|English]], [[French language|French]], [[Hebrew]], [[Aramaic]], [[Latin]] and [[Greek language|Greek]].<ref>Sohail H. Hashmi in ''Just Wars, Holy Wars, and Jihads: Christian, Jewish, and Muslim Encounters and Exchanges'', [[Oxford University Press]] (2012), p. 307</ref> * [[Naim Frashëri]] (1846–1900) was an Albanian poet and writer. He is the author of a total of twenty-two works: four in Turkish, one in Persian, two in Greek and fifteen in Albanian. He learned Ottoman Turkish, Persian, Arabic, Ancient and Modern Greek, French, Italian<ref>Robert Elsie (2005). Albanian Literature: A Short History. I.B.Tauris. p. 70. {{ISBN|978-1-84511-031-4}}</ref> * [[Sami Frashëri]] (1850–1904) Albanian writer during Ottoman occupation of Albania. He authored many books, dictionaries, and an encyclopedia in every language he knows. He was fluent in Albanian, Turkish, Greek, French, Italian, Arabic and Persian. * [[Arthur Rimbaud]] (1854–1891) French Symbolist poet. After retiring from writing he went on ambitious language learning program while traveling around Europe and the Middle East; mastering Latin, Ancient and Modern Greek, English, German, Spanish, Italian, Russian, Dutch, Arabic, Hindi, Amharic,<ref>{{cite book|last=Nicholas|first=Jean|title=Complete Works, selected letters|year=2010|publisher=University of Chicago|location=Chicago}}</ref> as well as developing a working knowledge of several native African languages while living in Ethiopia.<ref>{{cite book|last=Robb|first=Graham|title=Rimbaud: A Biography|year=2001|publisher=W.W. Norton|location=United States of America}}</ref> * [[Robert Dick Wilson]] (1856–1930), American Bible scholar, spoke forty-five languages including [[Hebrew language|Hebrew]], [[Aramaic language|Aramaic]], and [[Greek language|Greek]], as well as all the languages into which the Scriptures had been translated up to 600 CE. * [[Nikola Tesla]] (1856–1943), Serbian-American inventor, electrical engineer, mechanical engineer, and futurist, best known for his contributions to the design of the modern alternating current (AC) electricity supply system. Read and memorized the entirety of many books, and was capable of speaking eight languages: Serbo-Croatian, Slovenian, Czech, English, French, German, Hungarian, Italian, and Latin.<ref name="ONeill2009">{{cite book |author=John J. O'Neill |title=Prodigal Genius: The Life of Nikola Tesla |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=dt-BAgAAQBAJ |date=May 2009 |publisher=Lulu.com |isbn=978-1-4421-7396-5 |pages=282–284}}</ref> * [[L. L. Zamenhof|Ludwig Zamenhof]] (1859–1917), creator of the constructed language [[Esperanto]], spoke eleven languages besides his own: [[Aramaic language|Aramaic]], [[English language|English]], [[French language|French]], [[German language|German]], [[Greek language|Greek]], [[Hebrew language|Hebrew]], [[Latin language|Latin]], [[Polish language|Polish]], [[Volapük]], and his native [[Russian language|Russian]] and [[Yiddish language|Yiddish]]. He also had an interest in [[Arabic language|Arabic]], [[Italian language|Italian]], and [[Lithuanian language|Lithuanian]], though he never claimed fluency in those.{{citation needed|date=September 2014}} * [[José Rizal]] (1861–1896) was a Filipino nationalist, writer and revolutionary. He was able to speak twenty-two languages including [[Spanish language in the Philippines|Spanish]], [[French language|French]], [[Latin language|Latin]], [[Greek language|Greek]], [[German language|German]], [[Portuguese language|Portuguese]], [[Italian language|Italian]], [[English language|English]], [[Dutch language|Dutch]], and [[Japanese language|Japanese]]. Rizal also made translations from [[Arabic language|Arabic]], [[Swedish language|Swedish]], [[Russian language|Russian]], [[Chinese language|Chinese]], Greek, [[Hebrew language|Hebrew]] and [[Sanskrit]]. He translated the poetry of Schiller into his native [[Tagalog language|Tagalog]]. In addition, he had at least some knowledge of [[Malay language|Malay]], and some other [[Philippine languages]] like [[Chavacano]], [[Cebuano language|Cebuano]], [[Ilocano language|Ilocano]], and [[Subanon language|Subanon]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Jose Rizal a revered hero abroad, not just PHL|url=http://www.gmanetwork.com/news/story/262449/pinoyabroad/pinoyachievers/jose-rizal-a-revered-hero-abroad-not-just-phl|accessdate=22 April 2013|newspaper=GMA News|date=19 June 2012|author=Andrei Medina}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|last=Zaide|first=Gregorio|title=Jose Rizal: Life, Works and Writings|year=1999|publisher=All Nations Publishing Co., Inc.|location=Manila, Philippines}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.filipinaslibrary.org.ph/filipiniana-library/filipiniana/70-features/212-rizal-and-language |title=Rizal and Language |publisher=Filipinaslibrary.org.ph |accessdate=18 November 2013}}</ref> * [[Emil Krebs]] (1867–1930) was a German polyglot and sinologist. He mastered sixty-eight languages in speech and writing, and studied 120 others. * [[Minakata Kumagusu]] (1867–1941), a Japanese author, biologist and naturalist. *[[Carl Gustaf Emil Mannerheim]] (1867–1951), Finnish military leader during the [[Finnish Civil War]] and sixth president of Finland, spoke [[Finnish language|Finnish]], [[Russian language|Russian]], [[French language|French]], [[German language|German]], and [[English language|English]], in addition to his mother tongue, [[Swedish language|Swedish]].<ref>{{Cite book|title=Mannerheim: Marshal of Finland|last=Jägerskiöld|first=Stig|publisher=University of Minnesota Press|year=1986|isbn=0-8166-1527-6|location=Minneapolis|pages=}}</ref><ref>{{Cite book|title=Mannerheim: The Finnish Years|last=Screen|first=J. E. O.|publisher=Hurst|year=2000|isbn=1-85065-573-1|location=London|pages=}}</ref> * [[Rıza Tevfik Bölükbaşı]] (1869–1949), a Turkish philosopher and politician, who "...was proficient in eight languages, including [[Arabic language|Arabic]], [[English language|English]], [[French language|French]], [[German language|German]], [[Italian language|Italian]], [[Latin language|Latin]], [[Persian language|Persian]], and [[Spanish language|Spanish]]"<ref>Metin Heper & Nur Bilge Criss, ''Historical Dictionary of Turkey'', Scarecrow Press (2009), p. 43</ref> in addition to [[Hebrew language|Hebrew]], [[Albanian language|Albanian]] and [[Armenian language|Armenian]].<ref>Hakan Ozoglu, ''From Caliphate to Secular State'', ABC-CLIO (2011), p. 48</ref> * [[Ahatanhel Krymsky]] (1871–1942), a Ukrainian orientalist and linguist; was an expert in up to 34 languages.<ref>[http://www.encyclopediaofukraine.com/display.asp?linkpath=pages\K\R\KrymskyAhatanhel.htm Krymsky, Ahatanhel. Internet Encyclopedia of Ukraine]</ref> * [[Sri Aurobindo]] (1872–1950), an Indian philosopher who, apart from his native [[Bengali language|Bengali]] and educational [[English language|English]], knew [[ancient Greek language|ancient Greek]], [[Latin language|Latin]], [[French language|French]], [[German language|German]], [[Italian language|Italian]], [[Spanish language|Spanish]] and other [[Languages of India|Indian languages]] like [[Sanskrit language|Sanskrit]], [[Hindi language|Hindi]], [[Marathi language|Marathi]] and [[Gujarati language|Gujarati]].<ref>{{cite book |last=Heehs |first=Peter |author-link=Peter Heehs |date=2008 |title=The Lives of Sri Aurobindo |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=EZTFrMZFOvcC&pg=PA43 |location=New York |publisher=Columbia University Press |page=43 |isbn=978-0-231-14098-0}}</ref> * [[Harold Williams (linguist)|Harold Williams]] (1876–1928), a New Zealand journalist and linguist, spoke more than fifty-eight languages.<ref>{{cite web|title=Harold Williams VOICE OF THE WORLD|url=http://www.nzedge.com/heroes/williams.html|work=The New Zealand Edge|publisher=NZEDGE.COM IP HOLDINGS LIMITED|accessdate=15 April 2013|year=1998–2011}}</ref> * [[Hrachia Adjarian]] (1876–1953), Armenian linguist. He spoke Armenian, Greek, Hebrew, French, English, German, Italian, [[Persian language|Persian]], Latin, Sanskrit, and [[Laz language|Laz]].<ref>{{cite web|script-title=hy:Աճառյան Հրաչյա|url=http://encyclopedia.am/pages.php?bId=2&hId=915|publisher=[[Armenian Encyclopedia]]|language=hy}}</ref> * [[Harinath De]] (1877–1911) could speak thirty-four languages including many eastern and western languages such as Chinese, Tibetan, Pali, Sanskrit, Persian, Arabic, English, Greek, Latin, out of which he was M.A in fourteen. * [[Sir]] [[Muhammad Iqbal|Mohammed Iqbal]] (1877-1938), perhaps one of the greatest poets of the [[Persian language|Persian]] language. Among his work of poetry, ''[[The Secrets of the Self|Asrar-e-Khudi]]'', appeared in the Persian language in 1915, and other books of poetry include ''[[Rumuz-i-Bekhudi]]'', ''[[Payam-i-Mashriq]]'' and ''[[Zabur-i-Ajam]]''. Amongst these his best known Urdu works are ''[[Bang-i-Dara]]'', ''[[Bal-i-Jibril]]'', ''[[The Rod of Moses|Zarb-i Kalim]]'' and a part of ''[[Gift from Hijaz|Armughan-e-Hijaz]]''. Mohammed Iqbal was fluent in [[Persian language|Persian]], [[Punjabi language|Panjabi]], [[Arabic language|Arabic]], [[Hindi language|Hindi]], [[Latin language|Latin]], [[ancient Greek|Greek]] and [[English language|English]]. * [[Martin Buber]] (1878–1965), [[Austrian Jewish]] philosopher, who "spoke German, Hebrew, Yiddish, Polish, English, French and Italian and read, in addition to these, Spanish, Latin, Greek, Dutch and other languages".<ref>Maurice Friedman, ''Martin Buber's Life and Work'', [[Wayne State University Press]] (1988), p. 8</ref> * [[Subramania Bharati]] (1882–1921), a great [[Tamil people|Tamil]] poet, learnt 32 languages (29 Indian languages and 3 foreign languages) including Tamil, English, Hindi, Sanskrit and Bengali. *[[Benoy Kumar Sarkar]] (1887–1949), an Indian social scientist, mastered many languages, and wrote in five: his native [[Bengali language|Bengali]], [[English language|English]], [[German language|German]], [[French language|French]] and [[Italian language|Italian]].<ref>Shruti Kapila, ''An Intellectual History for India'', Cambridge University Press (2010), p. 82</ref> * [[Ho Chi Minh]] (1890–1969), the Vietnamese [[Communist]] leader, became fluent in French, English, Russian, Cantonese, and Mandarin, in addition to his native [[Vietnamese language|Vietnamese]], through study and many years spent in exile.<ref>{{cite book|last=Duiker|first=William J.|title=Ho Chi Minh: A Life|year=2000|publisher=Hyperion|isbn=978-0-7868-8701-9}}</ref> *[[B. R. Ambedkar]] (1891 – 1956), founding father of modern India, architect of [[Indian Constitution]], champion of human rights and revivalist of [[Buddhism in India]]. He was great [[polymath]] (mastered over 64 subjects), linguist and polyglot. Ambedkar could speak ten languages, and more than seven fluently: [[Marathi language|Marathi]] (mother tongue), [[Hindi language|Hindi]], [[English language|English]], [[Gujarati language|Gujarati]], [[Pali language|Pali]], [[Sanskrit language|Sanskrit]], [[Bengali language|Bengali]], [[Persian language|Persian]], [[French language|French]] and [[German language|German]]. He wrote Pali dictionary (Pali to English). * [[Mahapandit Rahul Sankrityayan]] (1893–1963) could speak thirty-six languages and wrote in more than six.<ref name="Sharma2009">{{cite book| first = R.S.| last = Sharma| authorlink = | title = [[Rethinking India's Past]]| publisher = [[Oxford University Press]]| year = 2009| isbn = 978-0-19-569787-2}}</ref> * [[William James Sidis]] (1898–1944), an American [[child prodigy]] who knew eight languages ([[Latin]], [[Greek language|Greek]], [[German language|German]], [[French language|French]], [[Russian language|Russian]], [[Hebrew language|Hebrew]], [[Turkish language|Turkish]] and [[Armenian language|Armenian]]) when eight years old and claimed to speak about forty languages shortly before his death. He also created his own [[constructed language]], which was called [[Vendergood]]. Although Sidis was supposed to have an [[Intelligence quotient|IQ]] between 250 and 300 measured through psychological analysis, this was never confirmed.<ref name="sperling">{{cite book|last=Sperling |first=Abraham Paul |title=Psychology for the Millions |url=https://archive.org/stream/psychologyforthe032777mbp/psychologyforthe032777mbp_djvu.txt |year=1947 |publisher=Frederick Fell |location=New York |pages=332–339 |ref=harv |accessdate=26 November 2014}}</ref> * [[Andrzej Gawroński]] (1885–1927) was a Polish [[indologist]], linguist and polyglot, the author of the first Polish handbook of [[Sanskrit]], founder of [[Polish Oriental Society]] who was able to speak more than 40 languages and studied 100 others<ref>Fedirko, Janusz. 2008. Fenomenalny Multilingwista Professor Andrzej Gawroński (1885–1927). ''Alma Mater'' nr 2 (100), miesięcznik Uniwersytetu Jagiellońskiego [https://web.archive.org/web/20110927162126/http://www3.uj.edu.pl/alma/alma/100/16.pdf]</ref> * [[Agop Dilâçar]] (1895–1979), [[Turkish-Armenian]] linguist who was proficient in 22 languages. * [[Shuddhananda Bharati]] (1897–1990), an Indian revolutionary turned mystic author who wrote "over 250 published works, 173 are in [[Tamil language|Tamil]], fifty in [[English language|English]], six in [[French language|French]], four in [[Hindi language|Hindi]] and three in [[Telugu language|Telugu]]. Apart from these languages, he was also conversant with [[Sanskrit]], [[Kannada language|Kannada]], [[Malayalam language|Malayalam]] and [[Urdu]]."<ref>Mohan Lal, ''Encyclopaedia of Indian Literature : Sasay to Zorgot'', Sahitya Akademi (1992), p. 4199</ref> * [[Vladimir Nabokov]] (1899–1977) claimed to be trilingual "in the proper sense of writing, not only speaking, three languages". He wrote in English, Russian, and French.<ref name=Bodenstein>{{cite book|last1=Bodenstein|first1=Jürgen|title=The Excitement of Verbal Adventure: A Study of Vladimir Nabokov's English Prose Volume 1|date=1977|publisher=Рипол Классик|isbn=9785881083526|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=KWYSAwAAQBAJ}}</ref>
===20th century=== ====A-E==== * [[Aziz Ahmad (novelist)|Aziz Ahmad]] (1914–1978), a Pakistani poet, short story writer, novelist, translator, historian, research scholar, [[Muhammad Iqbal|Iqbal]] scholar and critic fluent in [[Urdu]], [[English language|English]], [[French language|French]], [[German language|German]], [[Arabic]], [[Persian language|Persian]], [[Italian language|Italian]] and [[Turkish language|Turkish]].<ref>[http://www.dawn.com/news/771912 ''Aziz Ahmed, literary research and controversies''], [[Rauf Parekh]], [[Dawn News]]</ref> * [[Shahab Ahmed]] (1966–2015), a university professor and scholar of Islam from [[Pakistan]] who was "master of perhaps 15 languages".<ref>{{cite news|title=An Extraordinary Scholar Redefined Islam|url=http://www.bloombergview.com/articles/2015-09-20/an-extraordinary-scholar-redefined-islam|date=20 September 2015|accessdate=26 October 2015|newspaper=[[Bloomberg View]]|author=[[Noah Feldman]]}}</ref> * [[Syed Mujtaba Ali]] (1904–1974), a [[Bangladeshi]] author proficient in 15 languages. * [[Nabi Bakhsh Khan Baloch]] (1917–2011), a Pakistani scholar who "has written in seven languages — [[Sindhi language|Sindhi]], [[Arabic]], [[Urdu]], [[English language|English]], [[Persian language|Persian]], [[Balochi language|Balochi]] and [[Saraiki dialect|Seraiki]]."<ref>[http://www.dawn.com/news/504664/dr-nabi-bukhsh-baloch-a-nonagenarian-scholar ''Dr Nabi Bukhsh Baloch: a nonagenarian scholar''], [[Rauf Parekh]], [[Dawn News]]</ref> * [[George Campbell (linguist)|George Campbell]] (1912–2004), a Scottish polyglot and a linguist at the BBC, who could supposedly speak and write fluently in at least forty-four languages and had a working knowledge of perhaps twenty others.<ref>[https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/articles/A12644-2004Dec19.html George Campbell Dies; Spoke 44 Languages] (The Washington Post)</ref> * [[Ahmad Hasan Dani]] (1920–2009), a Pakistani intellectual, archaeologist, historian, and linguist, who mastered thirty-five languages. * [[Hans Eberstark]]<ref>Jeremy Bernstein, ''A Theory for Everything,'' Springer (1976), pages 205 and following</ref> * [[Jon Elia]] (1931–2002), a Pakistani poet and scholar who was fluent in [[Urdu]], [[English language|English]], [[Arabic]], [[Persian language|Persian]], [[Sanskrit]] and [[Hebrew]].
====G-K==== * [[Meredith Gardner]] (1912–2002), an American linguist and codebreaker. German, Old High German, Middle High German, Sanskrit, Latin, Greek, Lithuanian, Spanish, French, Italian, Russian, and Japanese.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://articles.latimes.com/2002/aug/21/local/me-gardnerobit21|title=Meredith K. Gardner, 89; Cracked Codes to Unmask Key Soviet Spies|first=BART|last=BARNES|date=21 August 2002|publisher=|via=LA Times}}</ref> * [[Abdul Rahman Ghassemlou]] (1930–1989), a Kurdish political activist and economist, mastered eight languages that included his [[First language|mother tongue]].<ref>{{cite web|title=The Passion and Death of Rahman the Kurd: Dreaming Kurdistan|url=http://www.carolprunhuber.com/thebook.html|work=Carol Prunhuber|publisher=CarolPrunhuber.com|accessdate=15 April 2013|author=Carol Prunhuber|year=2010|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130825185956/http://carolprunhuber.com/thebook.html|archivedate=25 August 2013|df=dmy-all}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Dr Abdul Rahman Ghassemlou|url=http://www.saradistribution.com/abdurahmanqasimlo.htm|work=SARA Distribution|publisher=Foundation For Kurdish Library & Museum|accessdate=15 April 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=I wrote the book to denounce the assassination by the Iranian regime and the complicity of the Austrian authorities |url=http://www.kurdistanukurd.com/en/wtar.php?id=12 |work=KDP Press |publisher=Kurdistan Democratic Party KDP.Iran |accessdate=15 April 2013 |author=Dr Carol Prunhuber |date=28 April 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131212151847/http://www.kurdistanukurd.com/en/wtar.php?id=12 |archivedate=12 December 2013 |df= }}</ref> * [[Kenneth L. [[Lardil language|Lardil]], [[Navajo language|Navajo]], [[O'odham language|O'odham]], Polish, Spanish, [[Warlpiri language|Warlpiri]], and [[Massachusett language|Wômpanâak]].<ref>{{cite journal |title=Kenneth Hale: Kenneth Locke Hale, a master of languages, died on October 8th, aged 67 |url=http://www.economist.com/node/842137 |journal =[[The Economist]] |date=1 November 2001 |accessdate=5 web|title=UMonday Musing: The Man With Qualities|url=http://3quarksdaily.blogs.com/3quarksdaily/2005/06/monday_musing_t_1.html|author=S.
